column2: Income inequality: Gini coefficient (after tax)
column7: The Gini coefficient is a measure of the inequality of the income distribution in a population. Higher values indicate a higher level of inequality. Income here is measured after the payment and receipt of taxes and benefits.
column8: Household income is divided by the LIS equivalence scale (square root of the total number of household members) to address economies of scale in the household.

column2: Income share of the top 10% (after tax)
column7: This is the income of the richest 10% as a share of total income. Income here is measured after the payment and receipt of taxes and benefits.
column8: Household income is divided by the LIS equivalence scale (square root of the total number of household members) to address economies of scale in the household.

column2: Income inequality: Palma ratio (after tax)
column7: The Palma ratio is the share of total income of the top 10% divided by the share of the bottom 40%. Income here is measured after the payment and receipt of taxes and benefits.
column8: Household income is divided by the LIS equivalence scale (square root of the total number of household members) to address economies of scale in the household.

column2: Relative poverty: Share of people below 40% of the median income (after tax)
column4: Share in relative poverty (< 40% of the median)
column7: Relative poverty is measured in terms of a poverty line that rises and falls over time with average incomes – in this case set at 40% of the median income. Income here is measured after the payment and receipt of taxes and benefits.
column8: Household income is divided by the LIS equivalence scale (square root of the total number of household members) to address economies of scale in the household.

column4: Share in relative poverty (< 50% of the median)
column7: Relative poverty is measured in terms of a poverty line that rises and falls over time with average incomes – in this case set at 50% of the median income. Income here is measured after the payment and receipt of taxes and benefits.
column8: Household income is divided by the LIS equivalence scale (square root of the total number of household members) to address economies of scale in the household.

column4: Share in relative poverty (< 60% of the median)

column8: Household income is divided by the LIS equivalence scale (square root of the total number of household members) to address economies of scale in the household.

column2: Gini coefficient (after tax)
column5:
The Gini coefficient is a measure of the inequality of the income distribution in a population. Higher values indicate a higher level of inequality.

This is disposable household income. Income here is measured after the payment and receipt of taxes and benefits.

Household income is divided by the LIS equivalence scale (square root of the total number of household members) to address economies of scale in the household.
column11: Luxembourg Income Study (LIS) Database, http://www.lisdatacenter.org (multiple countries; 1967-2020). Luxembourg, LIS.

column2: Palma ratio (after tax)
column5:

This is disposable household income. Income here is measured after the payment and receipt of taxes and benefits.

Household income is divided by the LIS equivalence scale (square root of the total number of household members) to address economies of scale in the household.
